questions.text: The term _____ is familiar to IT professionals, who know that the best time to avoid problems is when the data is entered.
questions.explanation: GIGO means that inaccurate input data will produce incorrect or meaningless output, regardless of the system’s accuracy.

questions.text: In older systems, often the user interface mainly consisted of _____ screens that allowed a user to send commands to the system.
questions.explanation: Older systems used process-control screens that accepted command-line input to execute specific functions.

questions.text: The goal of _____ is to build a system that is effective, reliable, and maintainable.
questions.explanation: Systems design focuses on creating a system that operates efficiently and is easy to maintain and enhance.

questions.text: A(n) _____ does not distract a user and calls no attention to itself.
questions.explanation: A transparent interface is seamless and allows users to focus on their tasks without distraction.

questions.text: A(n) _____ is a data validation rule that is used to verify that data items fall between a specified minimum and maximum value.
questions.explanation: A range check ensures that entered data values fall within an acceptable numeric or character range.

questions.text: In a source document, the main part of a form, called the _____, usually takes up at least half of the space on the form and contains captions and areas for entering variable data.
questions.explanation: The body zone of a form is where most user-entered or variable data is captured.

questions.text: Web-based software usually requires additional layers, called _____, to communicate with existing software and legacy systems.
questions.explanation: Middleware connects web-based applications with other software or databases, ensuring integration.

questions.text: In the event of a file catastrophe, _____ can be used to restore the file or database to its current state at the time of the last backup.
questions.explanation: Recovery procedures restore lost data and restore system operations after corruption or failure.

questions.text: _____ combine data from different item attributes, or characteristics, to build a code.
questions.explanation: Derivation codes are created by combining elements from multiple characteristics to produce meaningful identifiers.

questions.text: During the systems design phase, _____ are used to organise, access, and maintain data structures.
questions.explanation: Key fields uniquely identify records and maintain data relationships within databases.

questions.text: The complete definition of a database, including descriptions of all fields, tables, and relationships, is called a _____.
questions.explanation: A schema defines the database structure, detailing tables, fields, and their interrelationships.

questions.text: Designing tables is easier if a _____ is used to show a table’s structure, fields, and primary key.
questions.explanation: A standard notation format, like Crow’s Foot notation, visually depicts database table relationships.

questions.text: _____ is the starting point for measuring the performance, accuracy, and completeness of the finished system before entering the systems design phase.
questions.explanation: The SRS document defines expected functionality and serves as the benchmark for later evaluation.

questions.text: _____ is a model of software deployment where an application is hosted as a service provided to customers over the Internet.
questions.explanation: SaaS delivers applications online, eliminating the need for local installation or maintenance.

questions.text: The _____ environment enhances interactive experiences, including wikis and blogs, and social networking applications.
questions.explanation: Web 2.0 promotes user interactivity and collaboration through social and content-sharing platforms.

questions.text: When software is purchased, a _____ is being bought that gives the purchaser the right to use the software under certain terms and conditions.
questions.explanation: A software license grants legal rights to use the software according to defined conditions.

questions.text: _____ is the transfer of information systems development, operation, or maintenance to an outside firm that provides these services for a fee.
questions.explanation: Outsourcing involves contracting external specialists to manage parts of IT operations or development.

questions.text: _____ is a model for enabling ubiquitous, convenient, on-demand network access to a shared pool of configurable computing resources.
questions.explanation: Cloud computing allows on-demand access to shared resources like servers, storage, and applications.

questions.text: Which of the following is true of a traditional systems development environment?
options: Many applications require substantial desktop computing power and resources.
Systems are developed and delivered in an Internet-based framework.
Systems are easily scalable and can run on multiple hardware environments.
Internet-based development treats the traditional environment as the platform, rather than a channel.
questions.correctAnswer: Many applications require substantial desktop computing power and resources.
questions.explanation: Traditional systems typically relied on local computing resources rather than cloud infrastructure.

questions.text: In addition to configuring software, the IT staff can create a _____, which includes screens, commands, controls, and features that enable users to interact more effectively with the application.
questions.explanation: A user interface defines how users interact visually and functionally with the system.

questions.text: When companies acquire web-based software as a(n) _____, they can limit in-house involvement to a minimum.
questions.explanation: Acquiring software as a service minimizes internal IT workload since the provider manages it.

questions.text: A(n) _____ is a firm that delivers a software application, or access to an application, by charging a usage or subscription fee.
questions.explanation: An ASP hosts and delivers software applications to clients over a network for a subscription fee.

questions.text: Interface designers can obtain data, called _____, by using software that can record and measure user interaction with a system.
questions.explanation: Usability metrics measure how effectively users interact with a system, guiding interface improvements.

questions.text: _____ protects privacy rights and shields an organisation's proprietary data from theft or unauthorised access.
questions.explanation: Output security ensures sensitive data is protected when displayed, printed, or transmitted.

questions.text: A(n) _____ is a data validation rule that is used for applying to mandatory data items.
questions.explanation: Existence checks verify that required fields contain data before processing continues.

questions.text: A(n) _____ is a data validation rule that is performed on two or more fields to ensure that they are consistent or reasonable when considered together.
questions.explanation: A reasonableness check ensures related data values make logical sense together.

questions.text: _____ was pioneered in the early 1980s as a user interface that enabled complete interaction using the mouse and screen icons.
questions.explanation: The GUI revolutionised computing by enabling intuitive interaction through graphical elements.
